### Steps to reproduce
<!-- If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error. A complete runnable program is good. -->
start data import using IMPORT INTO, after some time, tikv start using space rapidly(might due to data compaction)
we have confirmed in another issue that those space are not taken by `import` dir on tikv, see https://github.com/pingcap/tidb/issues/44986#issuecomment-1609653360

during those time period, there're many pending compaction data and it's in flow control

comments_data.body: please ask me for logs during this period, it's too big to upload

@D3Hunter Is there any region balance issue in this issue, such that most of the import goes to a few nodes only? 
And of course TiKV itself should not allow the import service to continue when space is not enough.

![image](https://github.com/tikv/tikv/assets/3312245/bec071cc-daaf-4628-b921-2e4654804f9b)

quite balanced

> And of course TiKV itself should not allow the import service to continue when space is not enough.

the issue here is that TiKV itself exist with error due to fast drop disk spaceï¼ˆmight be caused by compaction) and unable to start again

I remember one of our users meets a similar problem. The TiKV itself starts a huge compaction that free disk can't afford. We opened https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/11502 at that time.

Do we have a plan to solve it? For example, change some compaction setting of rocksdb, or add precheck about overlapping before lightning ingest SST. @tonyxuqqi

Two issues in this case: 1) Region balance is not working properly in this case. TikV-9's store size is 300~400GB more than some other TiKV nodes. 2) There're large compactions that takes long time (the biggest compaction takes 2048s to finish and during this compaction all related SSTs cannot be deleted). The root cause is that there're too many L0 files (9.08K) being ingested to RocksDB and this triggers large compaction. But this is totally up to the workload and if lightning can somehow make SSTs not overlap with each other then it can be mitigated. And for workaround, reducing the https://docs.pingcap.com/tidb/dev/tikv-configuration-file#compaction-guard-min-output-file-size from 1MB to 512KB (or even smaller) can reduce the compaction job size.

currently, checking number of files at L0 and applying the ingestion is at two places, so lots of time passed between the checking time and using time. should we add another check for import service before ingestion?

Is it possible to dump the RocksDB log (at `$tikv_data_dir/rocksdb.info`.) and metrics? I'm not sure what happened. It seems that many L0 files compacts with a huge set of L6 files. (In normal cases, it should be compacted with L4 or even lower levels.)

I think this case is different from https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/11502. The latter is triggered by a TTL compaction in a cluster with few writes. And (I guess) this case relates with the blob write to L0 and L6. (Why L0 doesn't been compacted with lower levels? Are they huge too? Or the L0 files grows too huge by themselves solely?)

> L0 files (9.08K)

your screen shot seems not the cluster in the issue, here's what i got

![image](https://github.com/tikv/tikv/assets/3312245/796acb7a-c388-4303-becd-f49ad2851dee)

> Is it possible to dump the RocksDB log (at $tikv_data_dir/rocksdb.info.)

this part is gone since the cluster is scaled-in. the metric is still there
I added some comments at https://github.com/tikv/tikv/issues/15058#issuecomment-1619789754, I'm afraid this case is non-trivial...
https://github.com/tikv/tikv/pull/15379 should be able to fix it.
The issue should be fixed by https://github.com/tikv/tikv/pull/15379
